text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm live sourdough bread that's right
in this first part of a two-part series
we're gonna make what's called the
starter which some people jokingly refer
to as the world's most boring pet since
we have to take care of it and feed it
every day but while it is true this is
not going to lick your face or do any
cool tricks it's also true that your
schnauzer is not gonna make you a loaf
of the world's greatest bread which I
believe this is so with that let's go
ahead and get started with this
incredibly easy process and you get to
started what we'll do is zero out a
digital scale because we want to mix
together exactly the same amount by
weight of water and flour so I'm gonna
pour exactly 70 grams of water into this
container and it played safe I did use
bottled water but tap water should work
and then we'll zero that out and add 70
grams of flour and for that I'm gonna be
using a combination of half bread flour
and half spelt flour which is a whole
grain flour so that's the blend I like
but any flour is going to work here
theoretically as usual I make no
guarantees so I went ahead and dumped in
35 grams each of white unbleached bread
flour and some beautiful whole-grain
spelt flour and we'll go ahead and mix
that very well and I have no idea why I
grabbed a whisk that was a terrible
choice so as you'll see I magically
switched to a spoon and then what our
game plan is here once this is mixed
we're gonna cover it and let it sit for
24 hours and hopefully 70 degrees
Fahrenheit or as close to it as you can
get and then believe it or not what's
gonna happen here is that the wild yeast
and bacteria in the air and flour are
gonna start feeding on the starches in
the proteins and the mixture is gonna
slowly start to ferment so like I said
we'll leave that for 24 hours after
which it look like this and as you can
see we do have a few bubbles here and
there so things are happening oh and
fair warning the first few days of this
process you will get a fermenting smell
from this but it might not necessarily
be pleasant okay because not all the
bacteria in this are good and most of
this process is waiting for the good
bacteria to kill the bad bacteria okay
so don't get scared if it smells a
little bit off when you first start this
but anyway what we're going to do on day
two is
one more feeding of 70 grams flour plus
70 grams water and I'm gonna be using
the same mix of half spelt and half
bread flour through this entire process
so we'll go ahead and feed it and give
it a thorough mixing and if my math is
correct we should now have 280 grams
total of starter and then once that's
mixed we'll cover it and again leave it
for 24 hours it's 70 degrees oh and I
should mention you want to snap the lid
on super tight we want to let those
gases escape so I'm basically just
keeping out the fruit flies but anyway
we'll leave that another 24 hours and
this is what mine look like on day 3 and
as you can see we definitely have a lot
more activity going we have lots of
bubbles as our yeast colony is growing
as is our bacteria which again is
vanquishing the bad bacteria oh by the
way they are clear liquid that comes to
the top is called hooch which is made up
of alcohol and acids formed by the
fermentation process and it will
actually smell kind of boozy and at this
point on day three we're gonna begin the
regular feeding process and what that
means is we're gonna discard exactly
half of this mixture okay we want to
toss out exactly 140 grams and then we
will replace that with the exact same
weight 70 grams of flour 70 grams of
water and we're gonna repeat this exact
same process for about 7 to 10 days or
until we think we're done ok so what
we're trying to do is keep the same
amount of starter while still giving it
fresh food every day and this is the
most common question people are always
confused why do I have to throw away
half well because if you didn't
eventually you would have to move out of
your house so don't feel bad this is a
very necessary part of the whole
procedure so like I said every day for
the next week or so we will throw away
half we will feed it with equal parts
flour and water let it sit for 24 hours
and then do the exact same thing and
please do not miss a feeding do this
every day ok think of yourself as the
Brett Farve
of not letting your edible pet starve
and no I'm not going to show mine every
day this was like three or four days
later and you can see we have a good
amount of hooch on the top which is an
indication it needs to be fed and even
if one day you go to feed it and it
doesn't look good it sort of looks dead
just keep pushing on okay
whatever reason sometimes the process
sort of slows down but you'll see just
keep feeding it and you'll be fine oh
and by the way because this is sort of a
living creature
it is very customary to name it you know
names like starchy and hooch sour Joe
bubbles make bubble face those would all
work but you could probably come up
something even better but anyway we will
continue on and as the days go by you're
gonna notice the smell kind of change
it's always gonna have a fermenting
smell but in the beginning it's gonna
smell a little more sour sorta like an
old sneaker
whereas towards the end it's gonna smell
a lot better okay more yeasty fruity
it's gonna start to smell like something
you want to make bread with and that's
because our wild yeast is thriving and
any and all that bad bacteria is long
gone and then what we need to do when we
think our starters gone long enough is
tested using the following method okay
we're gonna toss half and feed it as
usual but we're not going to let it sit
for 24 hours what we're gonna do is
transfer it into some kind of jar and
then watch it for a couple hours and see
if it doubles or more in size and I
guess you could just observe it in the
container but it's just easier to see in
a clear jar like this and we'll mark
that to see where we started although
it's gonna be pretty easy to tell and
over the course of the next couple hours
mine definitely doubled in size and then
some and if that happens to yours
congratulations your starter is done and
ready to use oh by the way Jesse don't
freak out if you let it sit it will
collapse that's totally normal but
anyway we've passed our test and our
starter is now officially ready to make
sourdough bread with which unfortunately
you're gonna have to wait a little bit
to see because that's gonna be coming up
in part two which will be the next video
but in the meantime I really do hope you
start this process because if it works
you are gonna be blown away by how
amazing this bread comes out so stay
tuned for that but in the meantime head
over to food wishes comm for all the
ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as are we
enjoy
